I worked for a competitor of IBM for years, so I acknowledge my bias. That said, I found IBM to be a kind of cult to many customers in the 80s and 90s, and a few even now. At first, enterprises looked at IBM as the Cadillac of computing. They locked in many places with their mainframe computing the IBM 360 was a staple of business. The biggest places had sales staff with personal relations to the C level of enterprises and sole sourced the equipment. UNIVAC, DEC, Tandem and others to a lesser extent. As the 80s and 90s rolled around, Big Blue kept high prices on their Cadillac and although they rolled out their UNIX AIX and virtually invented the PC, the pricing was high, proprietary in an open source minded world and they lost market share. For one retail company, the Bd of Directors required competitive bidding, and even though any competitor could provide less price and equal or superior function, IBM would be awarded the work because we are used to them. Finally others stopped bidding the pointless exercise it was just to press IBM to keep their pricing down. When the old guard retired, and the enterprise realized the premium they paid for obsolete proprietary systems it was too late. They still used the IBM OS2 PC into the 2000s. They went from sales of billions to bankruptcy. I am convinced their cult belief in IBM and failure to modernize contributed. I did a study for multiple companies that illustrated if they moved off the bloated AIX systems to competitive systems, they would save millions. The paradigm shift always seemed risky, but those that moved were well rewarded. In the last 15 years, where IBM competed against Dell, HPHPE, Fujitsu, Amazon, Microsoft and others for data center refresh, cloud and other updates, they rarely stood the test, unless it was from one of those cultist enterprises who had decided before the bid. They still have a mainframe market it is expensive to migrate but not impossible. Their database product , PC, AIX and others are considered by most to be old iron. Even their cloud is a bit proprietary and pricey iron cloud. Watson has been discussed Their quantum computing research is admirable but given their history of trying to make things proprietary so they can keep price and margin high, I wont expect it to play well with others. It is vaporware somewhat. All said, their sales and margins and employee count are down to 23 of the numbers 10 years ago. The legacy of arrogance. I vote thumbs down. FWIW.

Enterprise Value is usually a better metric for the cost of buying the business than market cap because it takes into account the companys debt and its cash. Enterprise Value Market Cap Debt Minority Interest Cash. If a company had a 500 million market cap and 500 million debt and 50 million annual income, it wouldnt be any better value than the company with 1 billion market cap, no debt and 50 million annual income. The first company would have a lower PE ratio but both companies would have the same EVEBIT ratio. Because it also adds minority interest, you should divide by EBIT rather than earnings because EBIT doesnt have the minority interests share removed. Plus, its available in most stock screeners, including TradingView. TlDr EVEBIT is a better measure of value vs other metrics such as PE.

He said that wrong by referring to 50M income instead of 50M EBIT. What EVEBIT does is strip out the effect of how a company is financed. Say you have two companies both with the same EV 1B and the same EBIT 50M. One of them has no debt, so its 1B market cap and pays no interest costs its net income will be 50M minus whatever taxes it pays. The other one has 500M market cap and 500M debt, so its net income will be 50M minus interest costs minus taxes. They may have different PE ratios based on the interest and tax regime but the important thing to understand is that underneath they are the same operating business just financed different ways. So you have to evaluate the two things separately quality of the business how the business is financed.

Just let it ride a bit longer and see where its going.

First comes a long period of trial and error that I can no longer afford. I am happy that I got to study physics, pure math as I thought they would be my calling but they did not. I dont know yet what I would be passionate about to make a living out of it. I decided to chase money instead while studying something that interests me. Hopefully I will find something that I am passionate about along the way, but I have yet to find it, unfortunately.
That is bad advice. Many peoples passions are not marketable and will leave them in a bad financial situation.

The dot.com bubble was very different. Not to say that valuations could be stretched at this point. I was old enough to do the dot.com. Right around 30. I know way too many companies that were basically three card monty. Sucking up VC money. Padding sales data when they showed up at the offices. Pipeline stuffing. Also, essentially we will buy X or advertise c on your platform if you do the same with us. Just shuffling VC money around the room to look like platform had interest or their was sales. I wouldnt doubt there are probably some companies like that now. But that was so much about infancy. This is not infancy. This is massive corporations with massive earnings and cash hoards throwing that cash at being first movers ... its that important. It would be idiotic for the meta nvda msft types, downstream chip players and fabs, software value add players, to be burning through their cash as they are. They know history. They know what is playing out here. Having used ChatGPT for a myriad of things, my wife the same. I have been learning prompts, she just learn as you go, we are stunned at the impact on our lives and then I read and see what else is happening that makes what we are doing silly. When companies like msft are throwing down 125B on a single datacenter as an example. You just dont do that on hype. This race is critical to corporate survival and global balances of power. Hell even China is creating a regulatory body to ensure we dont end up AIing wwiii with all of it. Tech companies are readily letting people go, hiring at lower salaries bc AI is changing the landscape for standard computer science guys. Just look at the silly things your person at home is doing on social media with AI tools. And then imagine what the players are doing with the best minds and engineers in the countryworld. We havent even started to speak to timelines on healthcare and processing data regarding studies and time to insight on drug candidates. Learning is going to be accelerated by magnitudes and at speed we cant fathom. Things will be needed. Necessity is the mother of invention. It doesnt not fail. Power sources will be uncovered. People had been far and happy for a while. No more. Another anecdotal cliche, publish or perish...translation keep up and get it done or disappear.

PS even if it is a bubble, look how big the dotcom bubble wave was...MASSIVE! you just have to know EXACTLY when to get out, which is not as easy as it sounds. if youre as keen and as disciplined as you believe, youre going to do extremely well no matter how things work out. best of luck!

dot.com bubble had more merit than current AI bubble. Internet was going to revolutionize customer service and information access and each company started to have their own website. To me, this level of AI hype has not even materialized yet which scares me when it come to some of the stocks

Its pretty similar. OpenAI has a 100 billion valuation. ChatGPT isnt close to useful enough to bring in several billion a year. Similar to the internet, which was very useful but took a decade for tools and infrastructure to catch up ton valuations.

I dont fully understand why AI gets compared to the Internet so much. It seems to me its more akin to something like the steam engine. Were talking about something that will potentially replace millions of human workers. The Internet was and is more of a medium for work to be done through and for instant transactions. Just my two cents but I dont see how they are comparable at a technological level so Im not sure its accurate to compare them at a financial level. But I have a degree in computer engineering, not finance.

I would disagree with that. The current promise of AI is that it will revolutionize the back office processes in basically every company. Companies will become thousands of times more efficient when all of those millions of dollars they spend on paying employees to readwrite spreadsheets, PDFs, Microsoft Word docs, etc will no longer be necessary since AI will be able to do it in a blink of an eye. This is almost certainly technically possible and will happen to one extent to another. The unknown is to what extent will entrenched processes at these companies slow it down or stop it from happening altogether, but the potential to revolutionize how business is done is equal than or greater what happened during the rise of the dot coms, since that mostly impacted how companies communicated. This has the potential to automate everything else.

replies.text: Your table is missing a key piece of data, analysts usually give 12 month price targets, so how accurate did the analysts price turn out to be 12 months later? Also some websites chart out in a graph both what the analysts average price target was, and where the stocks price went overtime. When you do this for some stocks, like T for example, it shows that analysts consistently call it pretty undervalued, and yet the stock also consistently under performs the market andor loses value. By your logic stocks like T would have been a good buy, even though history shows that you would have lost a lot of money in it. On the flipside meanwhile stocks like NFLX and TSLA would have been called dreadful and highly overvalued investments by analysts at various points, when it was actually the best time to buy those supposedly overpriced stocks.

Analysts ratings and price targets are absolutely useless information

If the company is good, it will eventually go back on growth track like Chipotle and Eli Lilly or like McDonalds or Nike, it needs some serious stock picking skill and long time observing the industrial trend.

I read about analyst ratings about ISRG. I invested a small amount after some research. It has gone 20 since then and has been solid despite tech sell off. I think analyst ratings is helpful to screen companies and not go tits up. I think what is usually lost is that they give a price range and typically most of us dont take risk into account and just invest blindly.
Its a site where they aggregate analyst price targets for a large number of stocks. They keep track of how accurate each analyst is for a specific stock so you get a sense of who you should follow.

Its called momentum, you rode a trade that everyone was on and it kept rising just like when Tesla was hit before and other stocks before they stagnate or decline. Analysts are also chasing the hype since very few had 700 upside target on Nvidia before it tripled they keep adjusting depending on the flowtrend
All analysts literally do is move their price targets as the stock goes up and down. It literally is useless information

Not true. Take a look at stock OTGLY. Its video game company CD Project. It has gone up 40 in last 3 months. Yet I researched and 8 analysts think it is a sell and 4 say it is a buy. I still invested because I follow the company and think there is a significant upside and current analyst opinions are recency bias. So I believe analyst opinions are a piece of information. If you blindly follow then you might get burned but using their opinion as a piece of information to screen stocks is valuable.
If analysts truly had a crystal ball why the hell would they give such valuable information away for free?

Agreed. There are also good and bad analysts. I often read reports even from what I consider good services and shake my head at times when its a field I know a lot about. To reiterate, Its a data point. If all the analysts predict a thing even if its wrong it will affect prices.

... They dont. Analysts get paid. And they are supposed to give honest projections. Its not some scam like you guys believe it is. They research the companies, speak to insiders and try to project where the stock price will be in 12 months. They can be spot on with revenue and earnings projections and still be way off on the stock price. Thats the stock market

No one has crystal ball. Again I find it is useful to screen stocks. To follow their arguments for prices. Regarding other question I agree that it cant be 100 right. But some of the opinions are behind paywall. But you still get to see the consensus buysellhold. Also some banks etc are publicly traded right? So they have to be atleast somewhat open about their investments and cant just make shit up. Again we need to do our own research at the end of the day.

I mean analyst is not a protected job description so there is a range, but yes real analysts are good at analyzing the businesses. That the stock market is highly regarded makes share price harder to gauge.
I just find that 90 of analysts follow momentum. Very few of them go against the crowd. Thus their opinions matter very little

Okay but again this is insufficient information. Youre not making a bet on the company. Youre making a bet on the markets perceptions of the company being wrong. If the markets expectations equal that of your expectations, than you will earn the discount rate as your rate of return. If they exceed expectations than youre profiting in excess of the discount rate.

It doesnt have to be short term. It can very well be long term too. You absolutely have to consider market expectations. Because the market price of financial assets is the discounted projected future cash flows. A company can grow 100 , but if it falls short of markets projections, say 150, than the market price of the asset will fall as the investors do not have a claim to as large of a cash flow as they previously thought they did.

I might consider fedora bleeding edge which is upstream from CentOS but even that is a stretch. When you compare it to things like Arch even fedora is super stable. CentOS Stream is probably leading edge leaning towards stable though. I would consider it appropriate for a lab environment but not a dev or UAT environment where lots of folks were running centos as a way to get around paying for RHEL subs. CentOS is no longer a bug for bug mirror of RHEL which means that companies cant get away with just paying for RHEL in production and using free CentOS environments and piggy backing off their RHEL support for fixing issues in centos. Developers complaining about CentOS not being bug for bug that want to run it in their home lab is silly too. Anyone can get 16 free instances under a developer license and do whatever they want with them. To be fair this wasnt available at the time of the CentOs changes but it was very quickly implemented because Red Hat recognized it was a gap for legit use cases they want people to do without subs.

As bleeding edge as the next minor release of RHEL9. C9 Stream has systemd25238. Rocky 9 RHEL 9 rebuild has systemd25232. Mainline systemd is 256.4. Its a faster moving tech preview but by no means bleeding edge. For things like systemd, which have grown to be a fascinating multitentacled beast, its quite nice to get these improvements sooner as things have a tendency to periodically break looking at you, blkio. Peering it upstream with Stream provides greater value in evaluating upcoming software compatibilities instead of hoping people jump on alpha releases, then frantically releasing errata over the coming months. AFAIK, Facebooks server farms are all Stream.

You likely know, but for a random SQL dev lurking Make sure the execution plan is correct. Sometimes the DBMS will hold onto a plan it thinks is good but every now and then, you give it some parameters in your where clause and performances slows dramatically and its like the DBMS is drowning. Ive had a few 3am calls where these stored execution plans on the database are always the culprit. If youve got many to many relationships, consider simplifying your data in main table and replace the value to be an ID that references another small table with definitions for each ID a bridge table, I think theyre technically called?. Then, your tables will be lighter depending on the data and joins will be more performant.

If you think you can look at a stock, reverse engineer what the market is expecting for FCF growth or EPS growth baed upon its metrics, and then create a discounted FCF or EPS spreadsheet that is more accurate than the markets prediction, best of luck to you. Id rather go bottom up and make an estimate of FCFEPS growth and just ask the simple question does the current price of the equity make this a good investment without paying any thought to what the market prediction or sentiment is. Semantically, of course, it could be argued that I am wagering for greater returns than the markets prediction with such an investment, but thats not how I philosophically approach the question.
HAHAHAHAHAHA

I think you are dismissing these people as not getting it when we actually understand it quite well. I do question him using railroads as an example of an industry in decline. Sure, their market share of total goods being moved has declined relative to barge and semitrucks... but that is a function of the the number of roads and improved river ways expanding while new rail systems have stagnated. That doesnt make railroads a declining industry. The industry is more efficient now than 20 years ago, so train count may be down i dont actually know if they are or not, but this is made up for by longer trains and larger freight cars... if you actually look at the tons of cargo moved by the industry, it will be clear that the industry is doing more work today than it did 20 years ago. They do so more efficiently than they used to and with less personnel. So when referring to railroads as a textbook declining industry. I guess I wonder in what regards do they mean that its declining? The number of people employed? Sure. The number of train cars? Maybe? But when it comes to how many tonnage they move, the industry isnt in decline at all...
I think you two are talking about the same thing. Market predictionsprojections of future profits ARE informed by financial results in real time, no?
Ive been bitten by a lot of empty MS promises over the years as well but this is some more info

Perhaps declining is the wrong word to use. Railroads used to make up 60 of the US stock market by market cap. Now it is only roughly 2. Thats what I mean when I say declining. Suffice is to say, the point is that companies tech companies with insane growth potential underperforming railroads should demonstrate that the size and quality of a company is not what drives returns. Its the amount you pay for earnings.

Semantically, of course, it could be argued that I am wagering for greater returns than the markets prediction with such an investment... I was hoping I had acknowledged this by including this comment. Its more a question of framing or research process than anything else.

Yeah after reading this, I do not think we disagree, at least not a lot. I do not invest by trying to find inaccuracies 30 years in the future. My main goal is to find the discount rate, and we can use asset pricing models to try and find solid proxies for underlying risk characteristics, because at the end of the day thats the best predictor for returns we have. Thats why when discussing IBM as some shitty company, well that shitty company likely has a higher cost of equity. People demand their earnings less, therefore you pay less.

This is actually a common mistake people who fall in love with a stock do. The core fallacy is that of rebalancing in the same asset as it underperforms the rest. You are cutting from winning trades and putting more in a losing trade. In your case if the highest market cap stock kept going down, new stocks would take its place on the way down but you would keep rebalancing just like someone who is convinced there will be a strong bounce to take price where they feel price for that stock deserves to be. If you keep rebalancing in one place whether because highest market cap or because you are fanatic about a company then youd be putting your entire portfolio in a death spiral.

If top MC position is achieved not by stock B surpassing stock A gradually, but rather stock A gradually falling down from its top and going below its competitor B. And if it repeats enough times , then you will lose all your gains every time due to buy high sell low and gradually diminish your capital too !! Eg lets say AAPL at 2T today and NVDA at 1.9T. And you start your strategy today buying AAPL. . It goes to 2.1 T tomorrow. Good you gained on paper. And NVDA follows closely and grows to 2T. Good so far. On 3rd day AAPL falls down to 1.9 and NVDA stays at 2T. You sell AAPL and make a loss as 0.1T net loss from day 1 in their MktCap would be a net drop in share price too and hence corresponding loss inyour investment. Now you buy NVDA on day 3 when it is at 2T MktCap. Day 4 it goes up to 2.1T, AAPL catches back to 2T. Day 5 NVDA drips to 1.9T.... you sell NVDA and buy AAPL again making loss.... Rinse and repeat.....you see where this is going.... You will end up buying high ... riding higher but not booking the profit... sliding lower and selling and booking loss. Doesnt have to be just these two tickets jostling for top 1 and 2. It can be any two and your strategy degrades to buy high..sell low !!! You are only accounting for the general scenario that top mkt cap gets created by someone always beating current topper and all toppers always moving up and up. Thats not reality. The trouble with this logic js that Appl already has a significant presence in the SP500. Which means every institution with an algo has APPL in their sight. A 30 daily singular drop in APPL will almost certainly trigger a sell down on all algos trying to rebalance their portfolio. This momentum will very likely bleed over to all other stocks, so how do you find the next highest market cap stock when everything is bleeding? Another issue is the effect that Apple has as a tech company. While it does have the largest market cap, the top 7 are almost all tech related except for number 6 at saudi aramco, number 8 at Berkshire, and number 10 at elli lly. A drop in apple is likely to be devastating for tech evaluations. Considering its Apple and the fact that berkshire still has a significant portion of apple as its investment, that would mean that your largest marketcap strategy would end up ocilating between tech, oil, and pharma. I would suggest you not look too far in the past for this strategy because the market was much smaller then, and commisions were insane it wouldnt have been workable trying to do a daily rebalance or even frequent rebalancing. The Roth IRA was only available post 1998, so taxfree trades would not be possible prior. Theres also an issue of liquidity to consider if the strategy was successful. I.e. compounding returns at 22. Assuming you need to rebalance immediately, would dumping millions of dollars worth of shares in a collapsing stock give you the best price at exit and would entering the same cash into another stock give you the best entry. The last point of concern is that declaring the largest market cap as the winner is also only workable if we assume that market caps grow each year. Apple took dominance in 2013 with market cap. In 2015, they had a cap of 643b, in 2016, they still had market dominance, but their cap was 583b. Similarly, in 2018, they had a marketcap of 860b but the following year in 2019, they lost dominance in msft who had a marketcap of 780b whereas they were at 746b. The kicker was that in 2020 apple took back dominance at 1.29T, whereas msft was at 1.2T. Your performance would likely have been better at just buy and hold apple towards the end. Rather than adjusting for every variance. Furthermore, the yearly marketcap seems to ignore a lot of the nuances that happen in the year. Kind of like hindsight trading.

Arithmetic mean gives you the wrong answer. Geometric mean is what you want. Imagine you have a year that gives you 100 2x followed by a year that gives you 200 3x. Starting with 100, that means you had 200 by EOY 1 and 600 EOY2. Arithmetic mean gives you 150 2.5x on average, which implies you should have 100 2.5 2.5 625. Geometric mean gives you 145 2 3 2.45x per year, which implies you should have 100 2.45 2.45 600 with some rounding error at the end of the two years. Update looking at the raw data given for 19811994, the total return for OPs strategy over those 14 years is 360.7 4.607x. The geometric mean of that is 1.115x, or 11.5 per year, which is less than the posts stated 13.5 annual return for the SP between 19881994. Not sure where that number came from, but if thats the stated number from some authoritative source, then the backtest shows that this strategy loses to the index. If OP calculated that number using arithmetic mean, then wed need to know the actual yearly returns to make a reasonable comparison. Someone else can dig up that data and do that math though.

There are many issues in this election, but one central issue hasalways been what most significantly divides the Republicans fromthe Democrats. Republicans favor Free Enterprise Capitalism andseek to empower investors and industry to expand, grow, andemploy while limiting government spending. Democrats lean towardSocialism and seek to tax investors and industry for the purposesof distributing wealth to the masses via large social spending programs.Throughout history, societies that favor Free Enterprise Capitalism andgrow their economies via private sector incentives are societies that growand prosper. Societies that over-tax investors and private sector industrytend to stagnate and decline. Even China, which is an authoritarian, one-party state, greatly accelerated it's wealth and prosperity over the last 25years though capitalist reforms and incentives.In this election, the choice between a Free-enterprise capitalist candidateand a big government socialist candidate has never been more stark.Mr. Trump governed as the former and expanded GDP faster, 8 to 10 yearsfollowing the most recent recession, at all time record rates and he did itwith minimal inflation and very high employment.Biden/Harris passed record social spending and gunned inflation to the highestlevels in over 40 years, which led to high interest rates and everything from eggsto housing extremely unaffordable and wages/salaries significantly lagging thecost of living.The choice, should be very clear.

I am confused (and I am a CPA so I should not be that confused by an accounting entry). The story states that IBM expects a pre-tax charge of nearly $2.7 billion in the third quarter, related to a transaction involving the transfer of some of its pension plan obligations to a unit of Prudential Financial. Under the deal, nearly $6 billion of IBM's defined benefit pension obligations will be transferred to Prudential Insurance Company of America. To me, such a move would have NO Financial Accounting treatment unless the past actuaries miscalculated the pension obligation, and they need to fund an additional $2.7B. That said, the story continues that there will be no impact to earnings in Q3 or FY2024...Again, I am confused how a pre-tax charge (if necessary) would not impact earnings. If they correctly had a liability for $6B on their books then a pre-tax charge would not be needed to transfer those obligations to Prudential...but if the pension obligation was not adequately funded, then that would require a hit to earnings to increase the liability on their books. As originally stated, I am confused. Anyone think of a potential reason for a $2.7B charge that has no impact on earnings?

Here is a rundown of policy differences. This is not an endorsement.Mr. Trump recently stated that he supports reducing the top corporate income tax bracketfrom 21% to 15% in order to help companies like IBM to compete strongly against foreigncompetitors. 7 years ago, Mr. Trump spearheaded reducing the rate from 35% to 21%.Ms. Harris proposes increasing the top corporate rate from 21% to 28%, a 25% increase inincome tax IBM would have to pay instead of investing in it's growth.Mr. Trump wants to maintain the current long-term capital gains tax on sales of IBM stockat 15% and 20% for higher earners.Ms. Harris proposes taxing capital gains taxes as ordinary earnings. So an investor in the 28% marginal income tax bracket would see in increase in capital gains taxes on IBM stock sales from 15% to 28%, almost doubling the tax owed. Ms. Harris also proposes, with Mr. Biden,to impose the tax on "unrealized" gains, on IBM stock that an investor owns but has not yetsold. The unrealized gain tax would be imposed on higher earners.Mr. Trump lowered personal income tax brackets across the board in 2017. Those reductions will "sunset" (end) in 2025 if they are not renewed. Mr. Trump wants to renew them. Ms. Harris avoids the subject, but Mr. Biden has expressed disdain for the 2017 reductions. The increased standard deduction would also sunset. If the brackets sunset and increase to the pre-2017 levels, so too would the cap-gains tax with Harris's proposal.
